diagnosis.final_diagnosis: Genetic defect in CYP24A1 causing idiopathic infantile hypercalcemia
diagnosis.diagnostic_reasoning: The diagnosis was supported by extremely elevated intestinal calcium absorption (approximately 90% from ingested calcium) and the identification of a rare homozygous deletion in the CYP24A1 gene, leading to undetectable levels of 24,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. In vivo functional studies confirmed decreased 24-hydroxylase activity, further demonstrating the causal role of CYP24A1 in this case of idiopathic infantile hypercalcemia.
